titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Doug Johnson, April, 2016; machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cub√©.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2017-08-07T14:39-0700

did.abstract: Paulist Productions was founded in Los Angeles in 1960 by Ellwood "Bud" Kieser (b. March 27, 1929-d. September 16, 2000), a Catholic priest and member of the Paulist Fathers. Its initial television series, Insight, originally consisted of little more than Father Kieser delivering a lecture about Christian values on an empty stage. Though production values remained modest, the syndicated program's non-dogmatic, ecumenical approach was soon able to attract top-flight Hollywood talent who would often donate their fees back to the company. In its quarter-century of activity, Insight addressed issues such as poverty, racism, and war from a liberal perspective, while still maintaining a resolutely anti-communist stance, and winning nine Daytime Emmy Awards. In addition to Insight, Paulist Productions was responsible for the feature film Romero, and for a number of television movies and specials. It also produced several short films for classroom use. The collection consists mostly of scripts, photographs, and publicity material for Insight, as well as for various other productions. Many scripts are annotated, and appear in multiple drafts. Photographs tend to consist of scene stills and off-camera photographs, in the form of prints, negatives, contact sheets, and color transparencies. Publicity material consists primarily of press releases. There is a small amount of information about distribution, but virtually no production records or correspondence apart from cast and staff lists and notes written in scripts. There is also a significant amount of material about Ellwood Kieser. Most of this material consists of photographs documenting his travels and on-set activities. There are also many examples of Father Kieser's writing, though his autobiography, Hollywood Priest, is not present in draft or published form.
did.physloc: Stored off-site at SRLF. Advance notice is required for access to the collection. Please contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: COLLECTION STORED OFF-SITE AT SRLF: Open for research. Advance notice required for access. Contact the UCLA Library Special Collections Reference Desk for paging information.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical object belong to the UCLA Library Special Collections. Literary rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Paulist Productions Records (Collection 2300). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

acqinfo.head: Provenance/Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Joseph Kim on behalf of Paulist Productions, May 5, 2015.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Paulist Productions was founded in Los Angeles in 1960 by Ellwood "Bud" Kieser (b. March 27, 1929-d. September 16, 2000), a Catholic priest and member of the Paulist Fathers. Its initial television series, Insight, originally consisted of little more than Father Kieser delivering a lecture about Christian values on an empty stage. Though production values remained modest, the syndicated program's non-dogmatic, ecumenical approach was soon able to attract top-flight Hollywood talent who would often donate their fees back to the company. Actors such as Martin Sheen, Edward Asner, and Patty Duke starred in several episodes each, and dozens of other luminaries (for example, Irene Dunne, Carol Burnett, Walter Matthau, and Louis Gossett, Jr.) appeared in just one or two shows. Rod Serling, Michael Crichton, and William Peter Blatty were among the writers who offered scripts for the program, and Arthur Hiller and Ted Post directed several episodes each. In its quarter-century of activity, Insight addressed issues such as poverty, racism, and war from a liberal perspective, while still maintaining a resolutely anti-communist stance, and winning nine Daytime Emmy Awards.
In addition to Insight, Paulist Productions was responsible for the feature film Romero, and for a number of television movies and specials. It also produced several short films for classroom use.
In 1974 Father Kieser established the Humanitas Prize, which honors film and television writing that reflects on the human condition and inspires compassion in viewers.
Though no longer producing an ongoing television series, Paulist Productions remains an active company.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists mostly of scripts, photographs, and publicity material for the syndicated television program Insight, as well as for various other productions. Many scripts are annotated, and appear in multiple drafts. Photographs tend to consist of scene stills and off-camera photographs, in the form of prints, negatives, contact sheets, and color transparencies. Publicity material consists primarily of press releases. There is a small amount of information about distribution, but virtually no production records or correspondence apart from cast and staff lists and notes written in scripts.

There is also a significant amount of material about Paulist Productions founder Ellwood Kieser. Most of this material consists of photographs documenting his travels and on-set activities. There are also many examples of Father Kieser's writing, though his autobiography, Hollywood Priest, is not present in draft or published form.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This collection is arranged into the following series, most of which correspond to a production banner:
Series 1. Insight
Series 2. Capital Cities specials
Series 3. Reflections
Series 4. Bloomin' Human Films
Series 5. Values: Educating for Responsibility
Series 6. Buchanan High
Series 7. Miscellaneous productions
Series 8. Unrealized productions
Series 9. Father Ellwood "Bud" Kieser

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This series contains material on the syndicated television series that ran from 1960-1984. Photographs generally consist of black and white prints, negatives, and contact sheets. Color transparencies are not uncommon. More unusual are color prints and negatives.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: This arrangement reflects the original arrangement of the donor. Individual episodes are first listed in alphabetical order. The first subseries consists of scripts that had been in springback and three-ring binders in numerical order. The second subseries consists of clippings that had been arranged chronologically in three-ring binders. The third subseries consists of files that concern Insight generally, rather than specific episodes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes: photos of Kieser's trips to Mauritania, Djibouti, Kenya, and possibly Ethiopia. He was accompanied by John Amos, Levar Burton, Patty Duke Astin, and Dick van Patten; photos of Kieser and Amos testifying before the U.S. Congress; an article by Kieser about the trip.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains portraits of Kieser posing with the casts of various productions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains snapshots from Kieser's work, with Raul Julia, as an election observer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains snapshots of Kieser's wide-ranging trip to Europe, from Scandinavia to the Mediterranean.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Reviews and publicity material regarding Kieser's autobiography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains brochure; periodicals with articles about the prize; photographs of Kieser with Joseph Dougherty, Aaron Sorkin, Henry Winkler, and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains snapshots and negatives from Kieser's visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains snapshots of Kieser's trip, including Nagasaki Peace Park

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains writings by Kieser that were either unpublished or for which publication information is not provided.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains color negatives and one print of the Paulist Productions offices at 11575 Pacific Coast Highway, which had been the residence of Thelma Todd.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Contains off-camera shots of Kieser with the actors and crew on various productions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Includes card commemorating Kieser's ordination; visa for the Soviet Union; WGA pension plan statement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes a handwritten letter from Kieser describing the discovery of his colon cancer; obituaries and tributes; copies of faxes to Melinda Dillon and Martin Sheen with readings for the memorial service.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs and post cards of images of St. Paul in New York City, Washington, D.C., and various books.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Contains photographs of Spanish Camp, the community where Dorothy Day had lived.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of Kieser being interviewed with Irene Dunne, and by Regis Philbin & Sarah Purcell and Mike Douglas.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Includes published essays by Kieser, ranging from his college newspaper to occasional editorials in the Los Angeles Times.
